When I try some like `editorLangId == c || editorLangId == cpp || editorLangId == arduino || editorLangId == ini` in context menu. It not works. So I guess it is not supported yet. This logic would be very useful. üòÑ

data.title: Fallback file encoding
data.body:
As indicated in #17165, `files.encoding` can be used to set the encoding to use when opening files in vscode.
However it's not exactly a fallback encoding and not how editor like SublimeText works.
FWIK, SublimeText automatically detect UTF files using either the BOM, or by trying to decode the file in UTF8 and look if there's no invalid codepoint. If the file is not UTF then the fallback encoding is used.

Currently UTF8 is probably the default encoding for most people, but lot of non american people have to deal with at least one other encoding mostly for historical reason.

So usually I work with a mix of utf8 and Windows1252 files and if vscode can detect and open UTF files correctly my experience will be greatly improved.

Note that I don't ask for an autodetect encoding that never fully works, only an UTF autodetect features.

data.title: New feature request

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

I am requesting a feature here :

I always miss syn feature that If I install some extension in my office work station's VSCode, get that same extension installed automatically to my laptop's VSCode or another devices VSCode that registered under my email id.

Exactly same as we have in modern web browsers just login to the browsers and all the bookmarks, history, passwords and extensions start syn automatically. No need to waste time in setting up manually.

data.title: Old webview page content will be updated to newly generated webview page
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

In the [REST Client](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=humao.rest-client) extension, we use the `vscode.PreviewHtml` command to preview the response. To render different responses in different webview pages, we set different uris to the response view page, like `rest-response://authority/response-preview/1489729942929` and `rest-response://authority/response-preview/1489729991935`.

And in vscode version __<=1.7.2__, the behavior of this command works as expected and users are able to switch between the response webview pages to view corresponding result. While currently, when I switch to an old webview page, the content of the webpage is updated to newly generated webview page.

data.title: Linkify terminal paths without any path separators

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Follow up from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22528, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/22602

Currently we're limited to the current workspace (knowledge of shell's cwd is blocked on https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/20676), but it would be good to linkify files in the current directory that don't have path separators. This would linkify the files in `ls` for example:

```
‚ùØ ls
build       node_modules  scripts  appveyor.yml     issue_template.md  npm-shrinkwrap.json  product.json           tsfmt.json
extensions  out           src      CONTRIBUTING.md  jsconfig.json      OSSREADME.json       README.md              tslint.json
i18n        resources     test     gulpfile.js      LICENSE.txt        package.json         ThirdPartyNotices.txt
```

data.title: [debug] VS Code fails to spawn external terminal on Linux.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

From a debug adapter, send `runInTerminal` command with this argument: `{ kind:'external', cwd:'.', args:['bash'] }`.  

The terminal will fail to open, unless `env: {}` property is also added.    
However, according to the [debug protocol spec](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/blob/95f71d92f70e3e8ab29e1abbd10361d5b1118fdb/debugProtocol.json#L407), the env property is optional.

data.title: Full screen does not work after starting vs code form the command line within tmux
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Mac OSX Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open iTerm
2. run the tmux command
3. start vs code with the "code ." command
4. Click the full screen button on the opened window. In OS X its the right most button of the three buttons that appear at the top left of every window

I would expect at this point for vs code to run full screen. Instead nothing happens.

data.title: Node debugger not stopping on breakpoints when connected remotely to Docker
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOs 10.12.3

Forgive me if this isn't an actual bug, but the guidance [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/node-debugging#_source-maps) suggests that if adding a `debugger;` statement in my code works but adding a breakpoint doesn't, there might be a bug.

The setup:

- Node/Express app
- Webpack transpiling ES5

If this does indeed sound like a bug as opposed to a problem with my config, let me know and I'll get to work producing a minimum test case.

I've got the following `launch.json`:

```
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [    
    {
        "name": "Attach remote",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "attach",
        "protocol": "inspector",
        "outFiles": [
            "${workspaceRoot}/{dist,node_modules}/**/*.js",
        ],
        "port": 5858,
        "restart": true,
        "address": "localhost",
        "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "remoteRoot": "/usr/src/app/"
    }
  ]
}
```

And the relevant bit of my package.json:

```
"stack:debug": "docker-compose -f docker-compose-development.yml up",
    "debug": " NODE_ENV=development nodemon --inspect=5858 index.js",
```

The `stack:debug` simply brings up all the services needed to run the application in Docker containers ‚Äì including bringing up a node app by calling `npm run debug` as the `CMD` in the Dockerfile.

If I bring up my stack of services in Docker _except_ my Node app, and then `npm run debug` (to run in my host's Node), I can connect to Node and debug as expected. However, if I bring up the service in a container (using `npm start stack:debug`), manually adding a `debugger;` statement causes code to break execution; however, a breakpoint in VS Code does not.

Webpack is outputting the compiled files with inline source maps into `./dist`. I'm reasonably confident that I've got the `localRoot` and `remoteRoot` correct as, if I muck about with them at all, my breakpoints go grey. However, nothing I change with `outFiles` or `outDir` seems to make a difference, so I'm assuming that my problem is here somewhere.

Thanks in advance...

data.title: Scroll bar and minimap arrive at the start / end before reaching the first or last line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0 - insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

Steps to Reproduce:

Settings "editor.wordWrap": "on"

1.Take a file with many lines. This example was using angular.js 1.6.3
2.Scroll down the page using the minimap or the scroll bar to the end.
3.Note that the minimap or scrollbar has come to an end, but we still have more rows.
4.Go back to the beginning using the minimap or the scroll bar to start.
5.See that the minimap or the scroll bar has reached the beginning but we still have more lines.

Atom works properly.

Note: I know that VSCode has an empty space at the end in the files (this is cool), I believe this has no influence.

![scroll1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/24041757/9c10cd68-0aed-11e7-983e-30eb2ae25fbc.gif)

data.title: [find/ctr+f] Regex case [A-Z] v [a-z] doesn't work, unless "match case" is also on.
data.body:
to replicate: 

ctrl+f: `[A-Z][a-z]+`

>Find all the Capitalized words

I think regex should work independent of "case matching" settings in the finder, since regex is pretty good at identifying cases on it's own.

data.title: Feature request: `when` clauses for group metadata
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: 10.11.6

I've remapped a shortcut to `View: Focus Next Group`. This command will open an additional group if I'm on the last group and have fewer than 3 groups currently open.

It would be great to have a `when` clause to prevent this. A clause like `editor.isLastGroup` (or perhaps a combination of `editor.openGroupCount` and `editor.currentGroupIndex`) would allow me to prevent extraneous group opening. A similar check for `editor.isFirstGroup` would let me re-use the same shortcut to jump back and forth between the first group and the sidebar.

Thanks for your consideration!

data.title: Custom file types?
data.body:
Please add custom file types to VSCode. You should be able to select a regexp to verify the file name, be able to set an icon, and make very basic syntax highlighting (EXAMPLE:Imp. words: foo, bar, foobar).
And please allow the user to change already set icons for files, like Makefiles, C++ files, etc.
Thanks!

Please add a preview/source editor for Linux `man` pages and an icon for them. It'd be awesome because right now you have to make an edit, save, view on terminal, find bug, switch to editor, find related line, ......
It's too long! AND it'd mean more files support. Yay!

data.title: Auto-update doesn't work on MacOS when running as non-root user
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run Visual Studio code as a non-admin user when there is a pending update
2. Run "Check for updates..."
3. Try to apply the update

What happens:

The application is restarted, but the update will not have been applied.

What is expected:

The application is restarted and the update is applied.
